questions.text: Which of the following structures does not pass through the foramen marked with the black arrow in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The foramen marked in the image is the foramen ovale. The middle meningeal artery does not pass through the foramen ovale. It passes through the foramen spinosum.

The structures passing through the foramen ovale are:

  • Mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve 
  • Accessory meningeal artery
  • Lesser petrosal nerve
  • Emissary veins 

These structures can be remembered using the mnemonic 'MALE'.   

The structures passing through the foramen spinosum are:

  • Middle meningeal artery
  • Nervus spinosus (meningeal branch of mandibular nerve)
  • Middle meningeal vein

Related Pearl: Structures passing through skull foramina

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient who works with animal hides presents with a lesion covered by a black eschar on his arm. Microscopy of the pus sample revealed bacilli, as shown in the image below. Which of the following proteins is not associated with the toxin produced by this pathogen?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image showing gram-positive bacilli with a characteristic bamboo stick appearance suggest Bacillus anthracis. Serum opacity factor is not a protein associated with anthrax toxin.

Serum opacity factor is a lipoproteinase produced by some M types of Streptococcus pyogenes. It causes opacity when applied to agar gel containing horse or swine serum. It is used to determine the virulence of the organism. 

Bacillus anthracis is a large, gram-positive bacillus. It causes zoonotic infections in humans. It is non-motile and capsulated with a characteristic polypeptide capsule made of d(-)glutamic acid.

Virulence factors of B. anthracis include

  • A polypeptide capsule that inhibits phagocytosis
  • Anthrax toxins, which are made of three proteins

    1. Edema factor/Factor I An adenylate cyclase that causes tissue edema
    2. Protective antigen/Factor II Binds to specific cell receptors and mediates entry of edema factor and lethal factor into the cell
    3. Lethal factor/Factor III Causes tissue death
     

Clinical presentation of anthrax:

  • Cutaneous anthrax: It is seen in dock workers carrying loads of hides and skin of infected animals. Hence, it is also called hide porter's disease. At the site of entry of organism or spores, a papule develops in about 1–3 days. This develops into a vesicle that later breaks down into an ulcer with a black, central, necrotic eschar surrounded by edematous skin. The lesion is also called a malignant pustule. The majority of the patients recover spontaneously, but a few may succumb to septicemia or meningitis.
  • Pulmonary anthrax: It is caused by inhaling spores. It is seen in wool sorters. The infection from the lung spreads to the mediastinal lymph nodes and causes hemorrhagic pneumonitis. 
  • Intestinal anthrax: It is rare and is caused due to ingestion of infected animals. 
  • Anthrax meningitis or meningoencephalitis: This is a fatal infection that occurs when the infection spreads to the CNS hematogenously. 

Related Pearl: Differentiating features between anthrax and anthracoid bacilli.

The following are the Differentiating features between anthrax and anthracoid bacilli.

S.N. Characteristics Anthrax Bacilli Anthracoid Bacilli
1. Motility Non-Motile Generally Motile
2. Capsule Capsulated Non-Capsulated
3. Shape Grow in long chains Grow in short chains
4. Medusa Head Colony Present Not Present
5. Growth in Penicillin Agar (10 units/ml) No Growth Grow Usually
6. Hemolysis Hemolysis absent or weak. Usually well marked
7. Gelatin Liquefaction Slow Gelatin Liquefaction Rapid Gelatin Liquefaction
8. Turbidity No Turbidity in broth Turbidity usually
9. Salicin Fermentation Negative Usually Positive
10. Growth at 45°C No Growth Grows usually
11. Chloral Hydrate Growth inhibited by  Chloral Hydrate Not Inhibited
12. Gamma Phage Susceptible to gamma phage Not susceptible
13. Pathogenesis Pathogenic to laboratory animals Not pathogenic

Related Pearl: Organisms and selective Culture Media

questions.text: Which of the following diagnoses have the hematology findings given below?
questions.solution:
The findings present in the above hematology slide are basophilic stippling  (punctate basophilia) with Cabot’s ring . They are features seen in chronic lead poisoning (also called plumbism or saturnism).

Clinical features include:

  • A - Anemia with basophilic stippling
  • B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)
  • C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)
  • D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy
  • E - Encephalopathy (Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsion, and coma)
  • F - Facial pallor -earliest sign

Other Options:

  • Minamata disease: Chronic mercury poisoning can show anemia secondary to GI hemorrhage.
  • Chronic iron toxicity: In severe cases, can present with leucocytosis and anemia (due to blood loss).
  • Arsenic poisoning: Can induce microcytic hypochromic anemia or hemolytic anemia.

Related Pearl: Lead Poisoning/Plumbism/Saturnism

Lead Toxicity
Source of exposure

Occupational exposure

Lead paint
Route of absorption

Children - GI tract

Adults - Respiratory tract
Mechanism of action
  • Binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits
    • ALA dehydratase
    • Ferrochelatase
  • Inhibits pyrimidine 5' nucleotidase
  • Competes with calcium
Organs affected (acute toxicity)

GI tract, Bone marrow, Peripheral nerves
Organs affected (chronic toxicity)

CNS, Kidney

Characteristic clinical findings

(ABCDEF)

A - Anemia with basophilic stippling

B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)

C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)

D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy

E - Encephalopathy- Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsions, and coma

F - Facial pallor (Earliest sign)
Diagnosis Blood lead levels
Treatment Calcium EDTA; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text:
A patient with productive cough, fever, and breathlessness was found to have decreased breath sounds and a dull note on percussion on the left side. His X-ray is given below. Sputum analysis revealed a diagnosis of bacterial pneumonia. Which of the following pleural fluid characteristics would best fit the diagnosis, according to Light's criteria?

LDH- Lactate dehydrogenase
questions.solution:
The pleural fluid characteristics in a patient with bacterial pneumonia would be pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH of >0.6. The pleural effusion associated with bacterial pneumonia is exudative in nature. 

Light’s criteria can be used to differentiate between transudative and exudative pleural effusions. Exudative effusions will meet at least one of the following criteria:

  1. Pleural fluid protein/serum protein >0.5
  2. Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH >0.6
  3. Pleural fluid LDH is more than two-thirds of the upper limit of normal for serum. 

Exudative effusions occur when there is a disruption in pleural fluid formation and drainage because of local factors.

Causes of exudative effusion include:

  • Bacterial pneumonia
  • Viral infections
  • Pulmonary embolism
  • Malignancy. 

Transudative effusions will not meet any of the above-mentioned criteria. They occur when there is a disruption in pleural fluid formation and drainage due to systemic factors.

Causes of transudative effusion include:

  • Cirrhosis of the liver
  • Left ventricular failure
  • Nephrotic syndrome

Understanding the cause of a patient’s pleural effusion can help us diagnose the condition and determine management. 

The other options are incorrect as they are not in line with Light’s criteria for the diagnosis of an exudative effusion.

Related Pearl: Types of pleural effusion

Transudative Pleural effusion

  • Congestive heart failure (most common)
  • Cirrhosis
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Myxedema 
  • Peritoneal dialysis
  • Urinothorax
  • Hypoalbuminemia
  • Constrictive pericarditis
  • Superior vena cava obstruction

Exudative Pleural effusion 

  • Infections: Tuberculosis, pneumonia, intraabdominal abscess (like- liver abscess)
  • Malignancy: Pleural mesothelioma, metastasis, lymphoma
  • Connective tissue diseases: SLE, rheumatoid arthritis
  • Drugs: Amiodarone, bromocriptine, dantrolene, dasatinib, methysergide, nitrofurantoin
  • Others:
    • Pancreatitis
    • Asbestosis
    • Pulmonary embolism
    • Hemothorax
    • Chylothorax
    • Meigs' syndrome 
    • Dressler syndrome (post-myocardial infarction or cardiac surgery)
    • Yellow nail syndrome 

Related Pearl: Causes of predominantly unilateral pleural effusion

Predominantly right-sided pleural effusion

Predominantly left-sided pleural effusion

Cirrhosis of the liver

(hepatic hydrothorax)

 Acute pancreatitis

Amebic liver abscess

 Aortic dissection
 Meig’s syndrome Esophageal rupture

Cardiac failure

( B/L>>right-sided)

Dressler’s syndrome

questions.text: Shown below is the pelvic ultrasound image of a 28-year-old female patient with a positive urine pregnancy test. She gave a history of recent treatment for infertility. Identify the classical radiological finding shown in her right adnexa.
questions.solution:
The image shows the bagel sign seen in tubal ectopic pregnancy.

The bagel sign is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of a gestational sac in the adnexa with a hyperechoic ring. It is characteristic of tubal ectopic pregnancy. This sign has a positive predictive value of 95% in ectopic pregnancy. 

A normal corpus luteum can also mimic this sign but can be differentiated by a bimanual pelvic examination.

A ring of fire appearance is seen on the colour doppler in ectopic pregnancy on the periphery of the adnexal mass.  It is shown in the image below:

Other options:

Option A, Lambda sign: It is also known as the twin-peak sign and is seen in dichorionic pregnancy. The below image shows a schematic diagram of the twin-peak sign. A triangular portion of the placenta is seen insinuating between the amniochorion layers.

Option C: Double decidual sac sign on ultrasound is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy, as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac. It is shown in the image below.

 Option D: T sign is a USG finding in monochorionic gestation. It is thin and is T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the intertwin membrane. It is as shown below.

Related Pearl: Important radiological signs in OBG

Sign
Significance
Bagel sign
Gestational sac in the adnexa with a hyperechoic ring.
USG sign in tubal ectopic.
Ball Sign
X-ray shows a crumpled up spine of the fetus.
Radiological sign of intrauterine fetal death.
Banana Sign
Abnormal anterior curvature of the cerebellum due to the associated Arnold-Chiari malformation.
USG sign in open spina bifida.
Double decidual sac Sign
Two concentric echogenic rings separated by a hyperechoic space.
Normal USG appearance of an intrauterine gestational sac.
Lambda Sign
The chorionic tissue in between the two layers of the membrane between the twins.
USG sign seen in di-chorionic pregnancies.
‘T’ Sign
USG sign seen in monochorionic twins. As the intertwin membrane does not have any chorionic tissue it gives rise to ‘T’ sign in ultrasound.
Bunch of grapes sign
USG appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.
Butterfly sign
Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.
Cloverleaf skull
Seen in craniosynostosis
Empty amnion sign
Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the given dose-response curve:

choices.text: Drug B is the most potent
Drug B is the most efficacious
Drug C is more efficacious than drug D
Drug B is more efficacious than drug A

questions.solution:
The more the curve is to the left, the more its potency. Hence drug B is the most potent on the given dose-response curve (DRC).

Potency

  • It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response. 
  • A highly potent drug evokes a given response at low concentrations and vice-versa.
  • The more the curve is on the left in a log dose-response curve (DRC), the greater its potency.

Hence in the given DRC drug B is the most potent and drug D is the least potent.

Efficacy

  • It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug.
  • It reflects the capacity of the drug to activate a receptor and produce the response.
  • In the log dose-response curve, the perpendicular height represents the drug efficacy.

Hence in the given DRC, drug B has the least efficacy (Option B and D), and drugs A, C & D are equally efficacious. (Option C)

questions.text: The brace shown in the given image is _____.
questions.solution:
The brace shown in the image is the Milwaukee brace.

The Milwaukee brace is an active corrective spinal orthosis primarily used in the ambulatory treatment of structural scoliosis. Designed as a cervico-thoracic-lumbar-sacral orthosis (CTLSO), the main objective of the Milwaukee brace is to delay or eliminate the need for surgery. However, in recent years, the use of the Milwaukee brace has declined due to the availability and convenience of modern braces. Nonetheless, it is still employed for scoliosis cases characterized by high thoracic and cervical spine curves.

Option A: Boston brace is a type of thoraco-lumbo-sacral-orthosis (TLSO brace). It has a hard polypropylene outer shell with a soft foam lining inside. It is used in patients whose scoliosis curve apex is at T7 or lower. The below image shows a Boston brace.

Option C: Taylor brace is designed to control the upper and lower regions of the spinal column and support your spine whilst standing, sitting, and walking after spinal surgery.

Option D: ASHE brace (Anterior spinal hyperextension brace) is used in dorso lumbar spinal injury.

Related Pearl: Commonly used splints and their indications

Uses

Foot drop

CTEV

Milwaukee brace

questions.text: An 18-year-old male patient presented to the ENT department with the lesion shown in the image below. Apple jelly color of the infiltrate was noted on diascopy. Histopathological examination of the lesions revealed granulomas surrounded by multinucleate giant cells and epitheloid cells without caseation necrosis. Which organism is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above features are diagnostic of lupus vulgaris and the organism responsible is Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Lupus vulgaris is a low-grade tuberculous infection affecting the skin over the nose and face. Brown, gelatinous nodules with apple jelly-colored infiltrate are typically seen on diascopy. Perforation of the cartilaginous septum may complicate the condition.

Diagnosis is made by taking a biopsy of the lesion and performing a histopathological examination. As seen in other tuberculous lesions, granulomas with multinucleate giant cells and epithelioid cells can be found. Acanthosis and hyperkeratosis are also usually seen. However, caseation necrosis and acid-fast bacilli are usually not seen.

Treatment is with a combination of anti-tubercular drugs usually for a period of 6 months.

Other options:

Option A- Mycobacterium leprae causes leprosy which usually begins with excessive nasal discharge. The mucosa is initially red and congested, which eventually leads to crusting. Nodules on the septum may ulcerate, causing perforations. It can be diagnosed by histopathological examination of the nasal scrapings which show foamy histiocytes laden with acid-fast lepra bacilli, called lepra cells. 

A patient with leprosy is shown below.

 

Option B- Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis causes rhinoscleroma which has three stages. The atrophic stage resembles atrophic rhinitis, a graluomatous stage showing woody nodules, and then the cicatricial stage which shows scarring and adhesions. Biopsy reveals lymphocyte infiltration and two characteristic findings:

  • Mikulicz cells - foamy cells with central nuceli containing the bacilli.
  • Russell bodies - eosinophilic inclusion bodies in plasma cells.

A patient with a rhinoscleroma is seen below.

 

Option D- Rhinosporidium seeberi causes rhinosporidiosis which presents as a leafy, polypoidal, pink mass attached to the nasal septum or the lateral wall. The mass is vascular, it bleeds on touch and its surface is studded with white dots which are the sporangia. Histopathological examination of biopsy shows the characteristic sporangia which are round and filled with spores surrounded by a chitinous wall.

A patient with rhinosporidiosis is shown below.

 

Related Pearl: Rhinosporidiosis

  • It is a chronic granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi which is recently reclassified as a member of the protistan Mesomycetozoa
  • It is more common in the southern states of India
  • It affects immunocompetent individuals
  • Most commonly a waterborne disease
  • Clinical features: Blood tinged nasal discharge, frank epistaxis, nasal stuffiness
  • Findings: 
    • Leafy, polypoidal mass, pink to purple in color and attached to the nasal septum or lateral wall
    • Sometimes, it extends into the nasopharynx and may hang behind the soft palate
    • The mass is very vascular and bleeds easily on touch
    • Its surface is studded with white dots representing the sporangia
  • Diagnosis: Biopsy which shows sporangia

Histologic section showing sporangium (arrow) which is fully packed with immature sporoblasts at the periphery and mature ones at the center

Treatment: Complete excision of the mass with diathermy knife and cauterization of its base. Recurrence may occur after surgical excision. Dapsone is also used.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the needle shown below and the procedure it is used for?

choices.text: It is used in obstetric anesthesia
It causes rapid onset of anesthesia within 1-2 minutes
It is used along with catheter for continuous infusions for pain management
The blunt tip needle prevents accidental dural puncture

questions.solution:
The image shown is the 18 G Tuohy needle, which is used in epidural anesthesia. It does not cause rapid onset of anesthesia, instead has a slower onset of action ranging from 10-20 minutes compared to spinal anesthesia which has a relatively faster onset of action.

Identification points:

  • It has a blunt, curved tip (Huber tip) that helps to prevent accidental dural puncture.
  • The needle shaft is marked in 1-cm intervals so that the depth of insertion can be identified.

It is used in obstetric anesthesia, segmental blocks, and chronic pain management.

Image below shows epidural anesthesia set with Touhy's needle and epidural catheter:

 

Other epidural needles: Crawford needle (straight needles without a curved tip): has a greater incidence of dural puncture.

questions.text: The given image shows the progression from stage 1 to stage 3 of a dermatological disease in a female child. This disease is also associated with dental abnormalities, onychodystrophy, ocular, and neurological abnormalities. It is caused by mutations of the IKBKG gene. What is the inheritance pattern seen in this disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical images of stages 1 and 3 of the disease, along with dental abnormalities, onychodystrophy, ocular, and neurological abnormalities due to mutations in the IKBKG gene is suggestive of incontinentia pigmenti. The pattern of inheritance is an X-linked dominant inheritance.

Incontentia pigmenti manifests as a multisystemic ectodermal dysplasia that is usually lethal in males. It presents in females with skin lesions, dental abnormalities, alopecia, onychodystrophy, ocular, and neurological findings. It is associated with defects in the IKBKG gene. The lesions can be described in 4 distinct stages, which are:

  • Stage 1 - Erythematous vesicular rash
  • Stage 2 - Verrucous lesions
  • Stage 3 - Hyperpigmented streaks and whorls 
  • Stage 4 - Atrophic linear streaks or patches 

The images below show stage 1 lesions and stage 3 lesions along the lines of Blaschko respectively.

The cutaneous lesions are seen along Blaschko's lines (image below), which are lines of normal developmental growth patterns in the skin.

Extracutaneous abnormalities include:

  • Dental abnormalities like delayed dentition, missing or malformed cone‐shaped teeth
  • Onychodystrophy 
  • Alopecia
  • Ophthalmological abnormalities with retinal neovascularization
  • Central nervous system (CNS) abnormalities like microcephaly, seizures, neurocognitive, and motor impairments.

Management:

No specific treatment is available. Symptomatic treatment includes standard management of blisters. Ophthalmological follow‐up is required for retinal neovascularization monitoring and treatment. Orthodontist for dental abnormalities, along with speech therapy if required. Pediatric neurologist for CNS abnormalities and seizures.

Related Pearl: Inheritance pattern of important diseases

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia

(alpha1- antitrypsin deficiency)

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy who was treated with chemotherapy for a juvenile pilocytic astrocytoma of the optic chiasma presented with the following eye finding. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image above shows Lisch nodules of the iris, which is a sign suggestive of von Recklinghausen disease or neurofibromatosis type 1. Astrocytomas frequently occur with neurofibromatosis type I.

Lisch nodules are hamartomas that appear as tiny nodular pigmented lesions which protrude above the surface of the iris.

Ocular manifestations of neurofibromatosis type 1:

  • Eyelid plexiform neurofibroma gives a characteristic S-shaped deformity of the upper lid. It is texturally reminiscent of a "bag of worms."
  • Optic nerve glioma, a pilocytic astrocytoma, typically occurs in young children.
  • Bilateral Lisch nodules
  • Congenital ectropion uveae
  • Prominent corneal nerves
  • Congenital glaucoma
  • Spheno-orbital encephalocele, due to dysplasia of the greater wing of the sphenoid

The ocular manifestations of neurofibromatosis type 2 are posterior subcapsular cataracts and hamartomas of the retinal pigment epithelium and retina.

Other options:

Option B- The ocular manifestations of Von Hippel–Lindau syndrome are retinal hemangiomas and optic nerve haemangiomas.

Option C- The ocular manifestations of tuberous sclerosis are atypical iris coloboma, iris hypopigmentation, and retinal astrocytoma.

Option D- The ocular manifestations of Sturge–Weber syndrome are choroidal hemangioma, iris heterochromia, ipsilateral glaucoma.

questions.text: A test for reducing sugars is being performed on several urine samples. The reagent used for this test consists of all of the following, except ________.
questions.solution:
The test being performed is Benedict's test and Benedict's reagent contains all the above contents, except sodium hydroxide.

Benedict’s test is used to detect reducing sugars. It tests positive for all monosaccharides and most disaccharides except sucrose.

Composition of Benedict’s reagent:

  • Copper sulfate- provides the source of cupric (Cu2+) ions
  • Sodium citrate- complexes with cupric (Cu2+) ions to prevent its deterioration to cuprous ions spontaneously
  • Sodium carbonate- provides an alkaline pH

Principle: All monosaccharides and reducing disaccharides contain a free functional aldehyde or ketone group. When heated in the presence of an alkali, they are converted to enediols, which reduce the cupric compounds (Cu2+) present in Benedict's reagent to an insoluble precipitate of red cuprous oxide (Cu2O).

Substances giving a positive reaction on Benedict’s test:

  • All monosaccharides such as glucose, galactose, fructose, pentoses
  • Reducing disaccharides such as lactose and maltose
  • Glucuronic acid, homogentisic acid, and ascorbic acid

The color of the precipitate gives a rough idea of the amount of sugar present in urine:

Color of the precipitate Amount of reducing sugar
Green 0.5%
Yellow 1%
Orange 1.5%
Red 2%

Hence, it is a semi-quantitative test.

Related Pearl: Test for Carbohydrates

Purpose of test

Names of tests

Test for all carbohydrates

Molisch test

For reducing sugars

Benedicts test

Differentiate between mono- and disaccharides

Barfoed’s test                        

Moore’s test                                        

Fehling’s test

Differentiate aldoses and ketoses

Seliwanoff’s test

Rapid furfural test

Foulger’s test

Detect Deoxy sugars

Feulgen Staining

Test for Pentoses

Bial’s test

Test for Galactose

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient was brought to casualty in an unconscious state after a head injury. What is the name of the sign seen in this image?
questions.solution:
The sign seen in the image is the battle sign i.e. a skull base fracture associated with bruising over the mastoid process.

Skull base fractures are associated with:

  • CSF otorrhea or rhinorrhea
  • Hemotympanum
  • Tympanic membrane rupture
  • Battle sign: Bruising or ecchymosis behind the ear
  • 7th and 8th cranial nerve palsies

Other options:

Option A-Duret hemorrhages are delayed secondary brainstem hemorrhages. They occur in craniocerebral trauma victims with rapidly evolving descending transtentorial herniation. They are typically located in the ventral and paramedian aspects of the upper brainstem.

Option B- Kernohan phenomenon is an imaging finding resulting from extensive midline shift due to mass effect, resulting in an indentation in the contralateral cerebral crus by the tentorium cerebelli. 

Option D- Racoon eyes refer to bilateral periorbital bruising, seen in anterior cranial fossa fractures. (image given below)

Related Pearl: Signs of base of skull fracture

Signs of Base of Skull Fracture

  • Bilateral periorbital haematoma (raccoon eyes)
  • Battle’s sign (bruising over mastoid)
  • CSF rhinorrhoea or otorrhoea
  • Haemotympanum or bleeding from ear

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image and the site at which it is used for taking samples.

choices.text: Ayre's spatula used at the squamocolumnar junction
Ayre's spatula used at the endocervix
Cytobrush used at the squamocolumnar junction

questions.solution:
The instrument in the given image is a cytobrush which is used to take samples from the endocervix for a Pap smear. Ayre’s spatula is used to take samples from the squamocolumnar junction.

The instruments used for a pap smear are summarized in the image below.


The Pap/ Papanicolaou test is used for screening cervical neoplasia. The ideal time for the collection of a sample is around ovulation but can be done at any other time as well. 24-48 hours prior to the test, patients should abstain from vaginal intercourse, douching, tampon use, and intravaginal medications. The Pap smear should be obtained before vaginal examination, because the fingers may remove the desquamated cervical cells and give a false-negative report.

The patient is put in a dorsal position and Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is introduced. The squamocolumnar junction is identified and scraped with Ayre’s spatula. Endocervix is scarped with a cytobrush. Samples are spread separately on 2 different glass slides. The slide is immediately fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol. After fixing the slide for 30 minutes, it is air dried and stained with Pap stain or short stain.

questions.text: A concerned mother rushes to the OPD with her 4-day-old infant and worriedly points to the rash that appears as shown below.  Microscopic examination of this lesion revealed neutrophils. You reassure her of its harmless, transient nature.  Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image showing multiple vesiculopustular lesions distributed over the arms of a newborn, with the presence of neutrophils on microscopic examination is suggestive of transient pustular melanosis.

Transient pustular melanosis is a benign condition seen more commonly among African-American neonates than Caucasian neonates. They present at birth as a vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, and palms or soles. The pustular phase lasts for 2-3 days and no therapy is required. However, the subsequent hyperpigmented macules may last for up to 3 months.

Samples from the lesion can be cultured and smears can be prepared. They contain neutrophils and will not contain bacteria or aggregates of eosinophils. This distinguishes these lesions from those of pyoderma and erythema toxicum respectively. More dangerous lesions like the vesicular eruptions of herpes simplex and staphylococcal skin infections need to be ruled out by appropriate testing. 

Other options:

Option B - Mongolian spots are slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

Option C - Erythema toxicum is another transient condition characterized by small white papules on an erythematous base, which are usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week.

Option D - Cutis marmorata is a transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of the skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: Which of the following retractors is usually used in a Caesarian section?
questions.solution:
The retractor usually used in a Cesarian section is image 2, which is Doyen's retractor.

Doyen's retractor is used to retract the abdominal wall as well as the bladder for proper exposure of the lower uterine segment during Cesarian sections. It is shown in the image below.

Deaver’s retractor (image 1) is specifically designed for holding the liver out of the way during a cholecystectomy. It needs to be used carefully to avoid damaging the liver. It is shown in the image below.

Morris retractor (image 3) is a big retractor used to give maximum exposure in large incisions such as those used in the abdomen. It can improve visibility on one side of an incision by pulling firmly in that direction. It is valuable during the initial phase of a laparotomy. It is shown below.

Czerny's retractor (image 4) is a double-ended retractor used to retract wound edges for intermediate-type procedures. One end has a blade with a lip which helps to retract without the edge slipping. The other end has two prongs and helps to retract the ends of an incision. It is shown below.

Related Pearl: Identification of Surgical Retractors

Deaver's Retractor:

Doyen's retractor:

Morris retractor:

Czerny’s retractor:

questions.text:
According to the National Immunization Schedule, what is the dose of vitamin A that should be administered with the first dose of the vaccine shown in the image?

IU- international units
questions.solution:
According to the national immunization schedule, 1 lakh IU of vitamin A should be given orally along with the first dose of the measles-rubella vaccine, which is shown in the image.

The first dose of the vaccine is given at 9 months of age. It can be given up to a maximum age of 5 years. It is given along with the measles vaccine as it enhances antibody production and confers sustained immunity against measles.

Vitamin A deficiency arises mostly due to its inadequate amounts in the diet. It can present as night blindness, conjunctival xerosis, Bitot's spots, and keratomalacia. At later stages, it can lead to xerophthalmia.

The image below shows Bitot's spots.

It also increases the risk of developing measles, diarrhea, and dysentery. Skin manifestations include xerosis, scaling, and dermomalacia. Phrynoderma may also be seen as keratotic follicular papules affecting the thighs and upper arms. It is shown in the image below.

In patients above the age of 1 year, vitamin A deficiency is treated with 200,000 IU of vitamin A orally or 100,000 IU by intramuscular route. It should be repeated the next day and four weeks later.

Vitamin A is a fat-soluble vitamin, that plays an essential role in vision, reproduction, and maintenance of epithelial integrity. The various forms of vitamin A include retinol (storage form), retinal, retinoic acid, and beta-carotene. It is stored in the liver perisinusoidal stellate (Ito) cells as retinyl ester (retinol palmitate).

Related Pearl: Vitamin-A supplementation & treatment of Vitamin-A deficiency

Vitamin A supplementation
Target group
6 to 11 months age
12 to 59 month of age (1yr to 5yr)
Dose
100,000 IU (oral)
200,000 IU (oral)
Frequency
Once
Every 4–6 months

 

Note: A total dose of 17 lakh IU given as per the following schedule:

  • 100,000 IU is given with measles vaccine at 9 months
  • 200,000 IU is given with DPT booster at 15–18 months
  • 200,000 IU is given every 6 months (till 5years of age)

 

Treatment of vitamin A deficiency
Age < 6 months 6-12 months > 1 year
Dose 50,000 IU 100,000 IU 200,000 IU

 

Note: Route of administration is oral, in the form of retinyl palmitate.

Related Pearl: National Immunization Schedule (India)

***The 2nd to 9th doses of vitamin A can be administered to children 1–5 years old during biannual rounds, in collaboration with ICDS.

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

 

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. He underwent immediate amputation surgery of the left lower limb. The postoperative day 2 image is given below. What is the most likely change in peripheral vascular resistance following this surgery?

choices.text: Peripheral vascular resistance is the same
Peripheral vascular resistance cannot be calculated

questions.solution:
The above-given image shows a post-lower limb amputation and the peripheral vascular resistance increases after amputation.

The brain, kidney, muscle, gastrointestinal, skin, and coronary circulations are arranged in parallel circuits. Each tissue contributes to the overall conductance of the systemic circulation. Blood flow through each tissue is a fraction of the cardiac output. It is determined by the resistance and the pressure gradient. Resistance is the reciprocal of conductance.

Amputation of a limb or surgical removal of an organ removes a parallel circuit. This reduces systemic conductance and therefore increases the total peripheral vascular resistance.

Vascular resistance refers to the hindrance to blood flow in vessels. It can be calculated from measurements of blood flow and the pressure difference between two points in a vessel. Blood vessels branch widely to form parallel circuits that supply blood to many organs and tissues of the body. This arrangement permits each tissue to regulate its own blood flow. The total resistance of blood flow is calculated as 1/Rtotal = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + 1/R3

The total resistance of the parallel circuit will be much less than that of any individual blood vessel. An increase in the resistance of any blood vessel in the parallel circuit will increase the total vascular resistance.

questions.text: What is false about the condition, that is relieved by the technique shown in the picture?

choices.text: Presence of a frequent sighing during history taking

questions.solution:
The technique shown in the above image is of 'breathing in a bag' technique. It relieves hypocapnia in hyperventilation syndrome.

Hyperventilation syndrome is a habit of hyperventilation due to stress or any emotional upheaval.

Symptoms occur due to hypocapnia/hypocarbia due to carbon dioxide washout:

  • Fatigue, dizziness, headache
  • Chest pain, palpitations, sweating
  • If severe - carpopedal spasms, paraesthesias, and loss of consciousness may occur. Acute hypocarbia causes respiratory alkalosis and reduced ionized calcium, resulting in hypocalcemic symptoms.

The patient has a typical history of stress followed by symptoms and frequently 'sighs' during the interview.

Treatment for hyperventilation-associated hypocapnia is breathing in a bag. The patient is told to breathe in and out of a bag so that they rebreathe the expired air. This increases the levels of arterial CO2 and quickly reverts the symptoms.

questions.text: The image below shows the peripheral blood smear of an anemic patient showing characteristic findings. Which of the following options best explains the pathophysiology of the condition in which these findings are seen?

choices.text: Increased destruction of red blood cells

questions.solution:
The peripheral smear shows macro-ovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils which are suggestive of megaloblastic anemia. Among the given options, impairment of DNA synthesis best explains the pathophysiology of megaloblastic anemia.

Megaloblastic anemia may be caused by vitamin B12 deficiency or folic acid deficiency. 

Cyanocobalamin (vitamin B12) and folic acid are co-factors required for DNA synthesis. Thus, in B12 deficiency there is impairment of DNA synthesis that leads to defective nuclear maturation, ineffective hematopoiesis, and distinctive morphologic changes. These include abnormally large erythroid precursors and red cells. 

Peripheral smears in megaloblastic anemia show hypersegmented neutrophils, with five or more nuclear lobules instead of the normal three to four.

 Peripheral smear:

  • Macro-ovalocytes
  • Macrocytes may even appear hyperchromic, but the MCHC is not elevated
  • The reticulocyte count is low
  • Occasional nucleated red cell progenitors  
  • Hypersegmented neutrophils, with five or more nuclear lobules instead of the normal three to four.

Marrow:

  • Markedly hypercellular due to increased hematopoietic precursors.
  • Fine nuclear chromatin pattern of immature precursors (megaloblasts)
  • Granulocytic precursors also display dysmaturation in the form of giant metamyelocytes and band forms.
  • Megakaryocytes can be abnormally large and have bizarre, multilobate nuclei.
  • The derangement in DNA synthesis causes most precursors to undergo apoptosis in the marrow (ineffective hematopoiesis) and leads to pancytopenia.

Option A- Defective globin synthesis causes thalassemias. The peripheral smear shows microcytic, hypochromic anemia, and nucleated red blood cells. Marked anisopoikilocytosis is seen. Target cells that have an accumulation of hemoglobin in the center are seen. Basophilic stippling, fragmented red cells, nucleated red cells, and mild reticulocytosis are also seen.

Option C- Increased destruction of red blood cells causes hemolytic anemias. The peripheral smear findings vary depending on the cause.

Option D- Anemia due to reduced erythropoietin production is seen in chronic inflammation. The peripheral smear shows either normocytic, normochromic anemia or microcytic, hypochromic anemia as in iron deficiency.

 

Related Pearl: Causes of Megaloblastic Anemia

Vitamin B12 Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Vegetarianism
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Intrinsic factor deficiency
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Gastrectomy
    • Malabsorption states
    • Diffuse intestinal disease (e.g., lymphoma, systemic sclerosis)
    • Ileal resection
    • Ileitis
  • Competitive parasitic uptake
    • Fish tapeworm infestation
    • Bacterial overgrowth in blind loops and diverticula of bowel

Folic Acid Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Alcoholism
    • Infancy
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Malabsorption states
    • Intrinsic intestinal disease
    • Anticonvulsants
    • Oral contraceptives
  • Increased Loss
    • Hemodialysis
  • Increased Requirement
    • Pregnancy, infancy
    • Disseminated cancer
    • Markedly increased hematopoiesis
  • Impaired Utilization
    • Folic acid antagonists
    • Unresponsive to vitamin B12 or folic acid therapy
    • Metabolic inhibitors of DNA synthesis and/or folate metabolism

Related Pearl: Features of Peripheral Blood Smear in Different Anemias

Type of anemia

Microcytic anemia

Diagnosis

Peripheral blood smear

Thalassemia trait

Basophilic stippling, target cells 

Iron-deficiency

Elliptocytes, target cells

Sideroblastic anemia

Pappenheimer bodies, RBC dimorphism, ringed sideroblasts (Perl’s stain) 

Macrocytic anemia

Diagnosis

Peripheral blood smear

Myelodysplastic syndrome

Hypogranular or hypolobulated neutrophils, blast cells, giant or hypogranular platelets, Pappenheimer bodies

Minor population of hypochromic / microcytic cells (dimorphic), poikilocytosis 

Megaloblastic anemia

Hypersegmented neutrophils (>5 lobes), ovalocytes

Hemolysis

Polychromasia (purple reticulocyte) +/- spherocytes 

Chronic liver disease

Target cells 

Normocytic anemia

Diagnosis

Peripheral blood smear

Haemolytic anemia 

Anisocytosis, poikilocytosis, polychromasia, nucleated red cells 

Hereditary spherocytosis

RBC lack central zone of pallor, reticulocytosis

Glucose-6-Phosphate-Dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency 

Heinz bodies (revealed by special staining),‘Bite’ cells

Related Pearl: Morphological Classification of Anemias

 

Microcytic Hypochromic

(MCV <80 fl)

Normocytic Normochromic    

(MCV 80 - 100 fl)

Macrocytic Normochromic

(MCV >100 fl)

Iron deficiency anemia

Sideroblastic anemia

Thalassemia

Lead toxicity

Acute blood loss

Anemia of chronic disease

Anemia of renal disease

Hemolysis*

Bone marrow suppression

  • Aplastic anemia
  • Pure red cell aplasia

 

  

Megaloblastic:

Vitamin B12 deficiency

Folate deficiency

Thiamine deficiency

Drugs - Methotrexate, Zidovudine, hydroxyurea

Orotic aciduria

 

Non-megaloblastic:

Alcohol use

Liver disease

Hypothyroidism

Hemolysis*

 

*Hemolysis can be associated with macrocytosis because of compensatory reticulocytosis. However, MCV can be normal depending on the degree of hemolysis.

Note: In Orotic Aciduria, peripheral blood smear shows Hypochromic megaloblastic anemia.
